revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Ildaura Murillo-Rohde | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = September 6, 1920 | birth_place = Panama | death_date = {{Death date and age|2010|09|05|1920|09|06}} | death_place = Panama | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = Nurse, professor | known_for = Founder, National Association of Hispanic Nurses }} '''Ildaura Murillo-Rohde''' (September 6, 1920 – September 5, 2010) was a Panamanian-American nurse, academic and organizational administrator. She specialized in psychiatric nursing, held academic appointments at several universities and was a psychotherapist in private practice. Murillo-Rohde founded the National Association of Hispanic Nurses in 1975. She was a [[World Health Organization]] consultant to the government of [[Guatemala]] and was named a Permanent UN Representative to UNICEF for the International Federation of Business and Professional Women. She was named a Living Legend of the [[American Academy of Nursing]] in 1994.
==Biography== Ildaura Murillo-Rohde was born on September 6, 1920 in Panama. She came to the United States in 1945.<ref name=Feldman/> She completed a nursing diploma from the Medical and Surgical Hospital School of Nursing in 1948. She earned an undergraduate degree in the teaching and supervision of psychiatric nursing from [[Teachers College, Columbia University]]. She earned an MA in teaching and curriculum development and an MEd in education and administration, both from Columbia.<ref name=Papers>{{cite news|title=Biography|url=http://www.nursing.upenn.edu/history/Documents/finding%20aids/Murillo-Rohde%20Inventory.pdf|accessdate=July 28, 2013|newspaper=Ildaura Murillo-Rohde Papers|date=2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304043222/http://www.nursing.upenn.edu/history/Documents/finding%20aids/Murillo-Rohde%20Inventory.pdf|archivedate=March 4, 2016|df=}}</ref> In 1971, Murillo-Rohde was the first Hispanic nurse awarded a PhD from [[New York University]] (NYU).<ref name=Feldman/>
Murillo-Rohde was dedicated to the Hispanic population in her work as a psychiatric nurse and focused on cultural awareness in nursing practice. In her article Family Life Among Mainland Puerto Ricans in New York City Slums, she stressed that there could be a “culture within a culture” and that a nurse must know each culture well in order to provide the best care.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Murillo-Rohde|first1=Ildaura|title=Family Life Among Mainland Puerto Ricans in New York City Slums|journal=Perspectives in Psychiatric Care|date=12 October 1976|volume=14|issue=4|pages=174–179|doi=10.1111/j.1744-6163.1979.tb01545.x}}</ref>
Murillo-Rohde became an associate dean at the [[University of Washington]] and was the first Hispanic nursing dean at NYU. Murillo-Rohde founded the National Association of Spanish-Speaking Spanish-Surnamed Nurses (NASSSN), known as the [[National Association of Hispanic Nurses|National Association of Hispanic Nurses (NAHN)]] after 1979, and served as its first president.<ref name=Feldman>{{cite book|editor-last=Feldman|editor-first=Harriet|title=Nursing Leadership: A Concise Encyclopedia|year=2012|publisher=[[Springer Publishing]]|isbn=0826121772|page=393|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vIfdwgZrbnAC&pg=PA393&lpg=PA393&dq=ildaura+murillo-rohde&source=bl&ots=yNZx1pBy9b&sig=ohxo1H37RnEmNwGWlMr0rE61L1w&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Y-T1UciLLsz_4AP_yYC4DQ&ved=0CC4Q6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q=ildaura%20murillo-rohde&f=false}}</ref><ref name=About>{{cite web|title=About NAHN|url=http://www.nahnnet.org/AboutNAHN.html|publisher=National Association of Hispanic Nurses|accessdate=July 29, 2013}}</ref> In 1991, [[David Dinkins]] appointed Murillo-Rohde to a commission that examined the quality of care at New York City hospitals.<ref name=Panel>{{cite news|title=Dinkins Selects Panel to Review City's Hospitals|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/09/nyregion/dinkins-selects-panel-to-review-city-s-hospitals.html|accessdate=July 28, 2013|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=November 9, 1991}}</ref> In 1994, she was named a Living Legend of the [[American Academy of Nursing]].<ref name=AAN>{{cite web|title=Living Legends |url=http://www.aannet.org/living-legends-complete-list |publisher=[[American Academy of Nursing]] |accessdate=July 28, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120412055058/http://www.aannet.org/living-legends-complete-list |archivedate=April 12, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
Murillo-Rohde died in Panama on September 5, 2010.<ref name=Papers/> NAHN awards a scholarship and an educational excellence award in her honor.<ref name=NAHN>{{cite web|title=Dr. Ildaura Murillo-Rohde, PhD, RN, FAAN|url=http://www.nahnnet.org/NAHNFounder.html|publisher=National Association of Hispanic Nurses|accessdate=July 28, 2013}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of Living Legends of the American Academy of Nursing]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{see also|List of most visited art museums}} This article lists the most visited [[museum]]s in the world in 2017, as ranked by ''[[Art Newspaper]]'' Review Visitor Figures Survey (April 2018) and the Museum Index of the [[Themed Entertainment Association]] (TEA) and engineering firm (AECOM) (May 2018). It includes notable museums with more than two million visitors. The list includes art museums, history museums, natural history museums and science museums, but does not include archeological sites or historical monuments. revision.text:
[[Image:Metso 4.JPG|thumb|right|250px|Moomin Museum was located in the Tampere city library Metso up until December 2012.]] [[File:Free Travel Shirt Tampereen muumilaakso.jpg|thumb|A Moomin statue outside the Tampere city library Metso|alt=A dark metallic statue of a cartoon hippopotamus wearing a white t-shirt with the Wikipedia logo and signatures in various languages.]] '''Moomin Museum''' ([[Swedish language|Swedish]]: Muminmuseet, [[Finnish language|Finnish]]: Muumimuseo, formerly called Moominvalley) is situated in the city of [[Tampere]], [[Finland]]. Shown at the Moomin Museum are illustrations made by [[Tove Jansson]] (the creator of [[Moomin]]s), 40 miniatures, tableaux about Moomin events and a small (2.5 metres high) Moomin House. There is a total of about 2,000 exhibits on display. Also shown is the original Moomin Valley multimedia. It also has the Moomin Shop which sells gift items and Moomin Library which have Moomin books in many languages.
==History== The blue five-storey miniature [[Moominhouse]] was built by [[Tuulikki Pietilä]], [[Pentti Eistola]] and Tove Jansson in the late 1970s. The original idea was to make it round, like Jansson always made it in her illustrations for the Moomin stories, but since it was going to be displayed in a corner at the [[Bratislava]] biennale of illustrations in 1979, they decided to make it square instead. No [[blueprint]]s were made, the house was built freely, floor by floor, and it does not follow any particular architectural style but is influenced by many different styles. The ground floor was sketched by Tuulikki Pietilä's brother, architect [[Reima Pietilä]].<ref>Mirja Kivi: Mumindalen, figurerna som kom på museum, 2000: Schildts Förlag Ab, page 84-85</ref> Originally, a world tour was planned for the house after the 1979 biennale, but eventually it went on tour only in the [[Nordic countries]] in 1980–1983. Then it was taken to the atelier of Tove Jansson, since it needed some repairs after the tour. It was displayed again at the Art Museum of Tampere in 1986 and then got its permanent location at the new Moomin Museum, where it has been on display since 1987.<ref>Mirja Kivi: Mumindalen, figurerna som kom på museum, 2000: Schildts Förlag Ab, page 86-88</ref> Photos of the Moomin House serve as illustrations in ''[[An Unwanted Guest]]'', the last of Jansson's four picture books about the Moomins.
Up until the end of 2012, the Moomin Museum situated in the basement of the Metso building of the city library. However, during December 2012, the museum moved into the Tampere Art Museum basement. During the move, a small collection of Tove Jansson's Moomin illustrations were on display in the [[Museum Center Vapriikki]]. The fully renewed and renovated Moomin Valley opened for visitors on January 2, 2013. The Moomin statue outside the Metso building will remain in place, to remind visitors of the Moomins' old home. In 2016, the museum moved into Tampere Hall and renamed to Moomin Museum. The Moomin statue was also moved to its new place. The museum opened in June 2017.
==References== <references/>
== External links == *[https://muumimuseo.fi/en/ Moomin Museum]
{{The Moomin Series}}
{{coord|61|29|53|N|23|45|02|E|display=title|region:FI-LS_type:landmark}}

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=January 2017}}
The '''Music Education Policy Roundtable''' is a music education advocacy and public policy group made up of an alliance of organizations dedicated to ensuring the presence and perseverance of school music programs operated by certified music educators teaching sequential, standards-based music education to students across the nation{{which|date=February 2013}}. It was founded in June 2012 by the [[NAfME|National Association for Music Education (NAfME)]] and [[American String Teachers Association|American String Teachers Association (ASTA).]]. The organization was formalized in June 2012 with a roundtable discussion in front of the executive members of the fifty state music education organizations. The group lobbies the government for higher music education standards a few times a year.
The alliance of organizations that sit on the roundable include: * [[VH1 Save the Music Foundation]] * [[National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences|The Recording Academy]] * [[American Choral Directors Association]] * [http://www.aosa.org/ American Orff-Schulwerk Association] * [[American String Teachers Association]] * [http://www.chorusamerica.org/ Chorus America] * [[Drum Corps International]] * [http://etmonline.org/ Education Through Music] * [http://giml.org/ Gordon Institute for Music Learning] * [http://www.grammy.org/grammy-foundation GRAMMY Foundation] * [http://iSchoolMusic.org Innovate School Music (iSchoolMusic.org)] * [[League of American Orchestras]] * [[Music Teachers National Association]] * [[National Association for Music Education]] * [[NAMM|National Association of Music Merchants (NAMM)]] * [[National Music Council]] * [http://www.oake.org/ Organization of American Kodály Educators] * [[Percussive Arts Society]] * [[Phi Mu Alpha]] * [http://artsedresearch.typepad.com/quadrant/ Quadrant Arts Education Research]
== Inaugural Members == The very first meeting of the original “Music Education Policy Roundtable,” took place on February 7, 2011 at the NafME Headquarters (then MENC: The National Association for Music Education). This was prior to its formalization as a coalition, the inaugural members included::
* [https://web.archive.org/web/20130915051416/http://musiced.nafme.org/about/nafme-leadership/michael-a-butera-nafme-executive-director Michael A. Butera] – National Association for Music Education (then MENC: The National Association for Music Education) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20131023080514/http://musiced.nafme.org/about/nafme-leadership/michael-blakeslee-nafme-deputy-executive-director/ Mike Blakeslee] – National Association for Music Education (then MENC: The National Association for Music Education) * Marlynn Likens – National Association for Music Education (then MENC: The National Association for Music Education) * [http://musiced.nafme.org/news/nafmes-chris-woodside-discusses-the-federal-government-shutdown-and-its-impact-on-education/ Chris Woodside] – National Association for Music Education (then MENC: The National Association for Music Education) * Nancy Townes – National Association for Music Education (then MENC: The National Association for Music Education) * [http://www.jmu.edu/profiles/bethechange/hale-donna.shtml Donna Sizemore Hale] – American String Teachers Association * Mary Jane Dye – American String Teachers Association * Deb Bissen – American String Teachers Association * [http://www.artsjournal.com/dewey21c/2011/10/people-you-should-know-laurie-lock-music-and-arts-education-advocate.html Laurie Lock] – VH1 Save the Music Foundation * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140920110842/http://www.chrispurifoy.com/about/ Chris Purifoy] - Innovate School Music (iSchoolMusic.org) * [http://www.americansforthearts.org/about-americans-for-the-arts/staff/narric-w-rome Narric Rome] – Americans for the Arts * Heather Noonan – League of American Orchestras * Catherine Davies – Chorus America * Sam Hope – National Association of Schools of Music * Leo Coco – Nelson Mullins Riley & Scarborough, LLP

{{Infobox person | name = Neelamani Devi | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1938|09|01|df=y}} | birth_place = Thongjao Keithel Leikai, [[Thoubal District]], [[Manipur]], India | death_date = | death_place =Thongjao Manipur | occupation = Master potter | spouse =Naorem Shyamjai Singh | children = | parents = Kharaibam Devasingh Singh
Kharaibam Ongbi Sanajaobi Devi | awards = [[Padma Shri]]
Tulsi Samman Award
National Award for Master Craftsman
Samaj Kalyan Seva award
[[Lions Club International|Lions]] Karmayogi Award | website = | imagesize = | restingplace = | restingplacecoordinates = | othername = | yearsactive = | known for = Pottery arts | domesticpartner = }} '''Neelamani Devi''' is an Indian craftswoman and master potter from [[Manipur]].{{cite web | url=http://www.e-pao.net/epGallery.asp?id=1&src=Handicrafts/Neelamani2009_1 | title=Traditional Pottery Designed by Naorem Ongbi Neelamani Devi | publisher=E Pao | date=2016 | accessdate=January 17, 2016}} Her creations have been the theme of two documentary films; ''Mittee aur Manab'' by renowned filmmaker, [[Mani Kaul]], and ''Nilamani: Master Potter of Manipur'', by [[Aribam Syam Sharma]].{{cite web | url=http://www.e-pao.net/epSubPageExtractor.asp?src=features.profile_of_manipuri_personalities.donny_luwang.naorem_neelamani_pottery | title=Padmashree Awardee - 2007 in the field of Pottery | publisher=E Pao | date=18 June 2009 | accessdate=January 17, 2016}} The TV Series, [[Mahabharata (9X TV series)|Mahabharata]] also featured her works on one of the episodes. The Government of India awarded her the fourth highest civilian honour of the [[Padma Shri]], in 2007, for her contributions to the art of pottery making.{{cite web | url=http://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/LST-PDAWD-2013.pdf | title=Padma Awards | publisher=Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India | date=2016 | accessdate=January 3, 2016}} == Biography == Neelamani Devi was born to Kharaibam Devasingh Singh and Kharaibam Ongbi Sanajaobi on 1 September 1938 at Thongjao Keithel Leikai, [[Thoubal District]] in the northeast Indian state of [[Manipur]] and received the early lessons in pottery making from her mother. She lost her parents during childhood, but with sponsorship from the ''Khadi and Gram Udyog Mandal'', continued her studies at Somthal Pargana, Bihar and completed her training in 1960. Her career started as a demonstrator at the Directorate of Industries of the Government of Manipur, but left the job and returned to her village to start ''Pottery Training Cum Production Centre'' in 1966. There, she trained the local women in pottery making which is known to have helped them to earn their livelihoods. Devi has traveled in India and abroad with her works; she has been a member of the Indian delegation who participated in the ''Five Indian Artisans'' exhibition and demonstration at the [[Museum of Ethnography, Sweden]], as a part of the Festival of India.{{cite web | url=https://youforalltube.appspot.com/www.mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/pdf/nenl0407.pdf | title=Ministry of Home Affairs, Blog report | publisher=Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India | date=2016 | accessdate=January 18, 2016}} She also participated in exhibitions and demonstrations at several places in Japan such as the [[Hyōgo Prefectural Museum of Art]], [[Kobe]], (''The Art of the Adivasi''), Tobacco and Salt Museum, Tokyo, Tougen Museum, [[Shirane]] and [[Yamanashi, Yamanashi|Yamanasi]], [[Saitama Prefectural Museum of History and Folklore]], and Mithila Museum, [[Tokamachi]] and [[Niigata, Niigata|Nigata]] (''Indian Adivasi Art Exhibitions''). In 1986, renowned filmmaker, [[Mani Kaul]], made a documentary film on Devi, titled ''Mittee aur Manab'' and [[Aribam Syam Sharma]] followed suit in 2003, with his non-feature film, ''Nilamani: Master Potter of Manipur'',{{cite web | url=https://www.yumpu.com/en/document/view/11132685/c-o-n-t-e-n-t-s-ministry-of-home-affairs/11 | title=Profile on Yumpu | publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs | date=2016 | accessdate=January 18, 2016}} made for [[Doordarshan]], Guwahati.{{cite web | url=http://www.aribamsyamsharma.com/filmography.html | title=Filmography of Aribam Syam Sharma | publisher=Official website | date=2016 | accessdate=January 18, 2016}} One of the episodes of the Indian TV series, [[Mahabharata (9X TV series)|Mahabharata]] and the first three episodes of ''Mahabharata'' TV series made by French Television featured her pottery creations. The details of her work have also been documented in print in a book, ''Other Masters : Five Contemporary Folk and Tribal Artists of India'', published in 1998 by the Handicrafts and Handlooms Exports Corporation of India.{{cite book | url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/other-masters-five-contemporary-folk-and-tribal-artists-of-india/oclc/41132379 | title=Other Masters : Five Contemporary Folk and Tribal Artists of India | publisher=Handicrafts and Handlooms Exports Corporation of India | author=Jyotindra Jain (Ed.) | year=1998 | pages=88 | OCLC=41132379}} The book is a prescribed text for academic studies at [[University of Goa]].{{cite web | url=https://www.unigoa.ac.in/vrpp/hso-150-indian-folk-and-tribal-art-practices-the-contemporary-in-the-vernacular-one-credit-course-by-professor-jyotindra-jain | title=Indian Folk and Tribal Art Practices | publisher=University of Goa | date=2016 | accessdate=January 18, 2016}} Devi received two awards in 1986, the ''National Award for Master Craftsman'' with a Certificate of Honour from the Government of India and ''Tulsi Samman Award'' from the Government of Madhya Pradesh. During 2005–2006, she received two more awards, ''Samaj Kalyan Seva award'' during her trip to Sweden and the ''Karmayogi Award'' from the [[Lions Club International]]. The Government of India honoured again, in 2007, by including her in the [[Indian honours system|Republic Day honours]] list for the civilian award of the [[Padma Shri]]. == See also == * [[Aribam Syam Sharma]] * [[Mani Kaul]] {{portal|India}} == References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Devi, Neelamani}} [[Category:Recipients of the Padma Shri in arts]] [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:People from Thoubal district]] [[Category:Indian potters]] [[Category:Women artists from Manipur]] [[Category:Crafts educators]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Artists from Manipur]] [[Category:Women educators from Manipur]] [[Category:20th-century Indian educators]] [[Category:20th-century Indian women artists]] [[Category:Educators from Manipur]] [[Category:Women in craft]] [[Category:Women potters]]

{{EngvarB|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox person | image = Oliver Tobias (1969).jpg | caption = Oliver Tobias (1969) | image_size = 220px | name = Oliver Tobias | birth_name = Oliver Tobias Freitag | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1947|8|6}} | birth_place = [[Zürich]], Switzerland | death_date = | death_place = | othername = | yearsactive = 1968 – present | spouse = Arabella Zamoyska (2001 – present) | website = http://www.olivertobias.co.uk/ }} '''Oliver Tobias Freitag''' (born 6 August 1947), known professionally as '''Oliver Tobias''', is a Swiss-born UK-based film, stage, and television actor and director.<ref name="WhatsOnStage">{{cite news|last1=Editorial Staff|title=20 Questions with Oliver Tobias|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/west-end-theatre/news/02-2002/20-questions-witholiver-tobias_28073.html|accessdate=5 August 2014|work=WhatsOnStage.com, Inc|date=4 February 2002|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808060015/http://www.whatsonstage.com/west-end-theatre/news/02-2002/20-questions-witholiver-tobias_28073.html|archivedate=8 August 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Biography==
Born in [[Zürich]], [[Switzerland]], he is the son of the Austrian-Swiss actor [[Robert Freitag]] and the German actress [[Maria Becker]]. He came to the United Kingdom at the age of eight and trained at [[East 15 Acting School]], London. In 1968, he appeared in the original London production of ''[[Hair (musical)|Hair]]'', playing the prime rebel role of Berger.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Tobias|first1=Oliver|title=Stage|date=7 January 2011|url=http://www.olivertobias.co.uk/bluehorizons/otf_stage_11.htm|website=Oliver Tobias – The Official Website|accessdate=5 August 2014}}</ref> The following year, he starred in, directed, and choreographed the rock opera in [[Amsterdam]] and, in 1970, directed a production in [[Tel Aviv]].
==Film career==
Tobias's first role was in the feature film ''[[Romance of a Horsethief]]'', co-starring with [[Yul Brynner]], [[Serge Gainsbourg]] and [[Eli Wallach]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Romance of a Horsethief (1971)|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/88578/Romance-of-a-Horsethief/|website=Turner Classic Movies|publisher=Time Warner Company|accessdate=5 August 2014}}</ref> He then co-starred with [[Charlotte Rampling]] in the Jacobean tragedy ''[['Tis Pity She's a Whore (film)|'Tis Pity She's a Whore]]'', a film directed by [[Giuseppe Patroni Griffi]]. He became popular as Arthur in the TV series ''[[Arthur of the Britons]]'' (1972). [[Peter Weir]] then directed him in the TV series ''[[Luke's Kingdom]]''.<ref>{{cite book|date=22 May 1974|publisher=Australian Women's Weekly|page=24|title=Luke's Kingdom|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article45651440|accessdate=5 August 2014}}</ref>
Many other successful films followed, including ''[[The Stud (film)|The Stud]]'' in 1978 in which he co-starred with [[Joan Collins]], helping her to restart her career. In 1981, he starred in the British television series ''[[Dick Turpin (TV series)|Dick Turpin's Greatest Adventure]]'', where he played the character Noll Bridger, a Colonial North American. Tobias also starred in ''Smuggler'' (1981) a children's drama series, set in Cornwall in 1801. Oliver also appeared as The Devil in the promotional video for [[Ultravox]]'s 1982 hit "[[Hymn (Ultravox song)|Hymn]]".
In 1991, Tobias starred alongside Charles Gray in the sci-fi movie "Firestar – First Contact" for Ice International Films. In 1996, Tobias played Rebecque, an aide to the Prince of Orange (Paul Bettany), in ''[[Sharpe's Waterloo (TV programme)|Sharpe's Waterloo]]''. In 1998, he played Bassa Selim in ''Mozart in Turkey''. In 2000, he starred in the West End musical ''[[La Cava]]''. Three years later, he portrayed Percival Brown in the 50th-anniversary production of ''[[The Boy Friend (musical)|The Boy Friend]]'' and the next year toured in the rock musical ''[[Footloose (musical)|Footloose]]''. In 2005, he finished shooting the film ''An Airfield in England''. He has been acting in a variety of roles for German and Swiss TV and has recently reprised the role of Bassa Selim in Mozart's ''[[Abduction from the Seraglio|Seraglio]]'' at the Teatro Lirico in [[Cagliari, Italy]]. Tobias is famous for his voiceover work and was the narrator on the opening track of [[DJ Shadow]]'s 2006 album ''[[The Outsider (DJ Shadow album)|The Outsider]]''.
==Personal life==
In 2001, he married Arabella Zamoyska, with whom he has two boys.
==Film and television== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Film !! Role |- |1969|| ''[[Arthur? Arthur!]]'' || Peter 'Bobo' Jackson |- |1970|| ''[[Romance of a Horsethief]]'' || Zanvill Kradnik |- |1971|| ''[[Addio fratello crudele (film)|'Tis Pity She's a Whore]]'' || Giovanni |- |1973|| ''[[The God King]]'' || General Miara |- |1978|| ''[[The Stud (film)|The Stud]]'' || Tony Blake |- |1979|| ''[[Arabian Adventure]]'' || Prince Hasan |- |1979|| ''[[A Nightingale Sang in Berkeley Square (film)|A Nightingale Sang in Berkeley Square]]'' || Foxy |- |1983|| ''[[The Wicked Lady (1983 film)|The Wicked Lady]]'' || Kit Locksby |- |1986|| ''[[Operation Nam]]'' (''Cobra Mission'') || Richard Wagner |- |1986|| ''Johann Strauss: The King Without a Crown'' || Johann Strauss |- |1993|| ''Nexus'' || |- |1994|| ''Broken Lullaby'' || |- |1994|| ''[[Vendetta (1995 film)|Vendetta]]'' || Colonel de Piemonte |- |1994|| ''Savage Hearts'' || Country Gent |- |1997|| ''Breeders'' || Police Lt. Moore |- |1997|| ''[[Darkness Falls (1999 film)|Darkness Falls]]'' || The Money Dealer |- |1998|| ''[[The Brylcreem Boys]]'' || Hans Jorg Wolff |- |1998|| ''Mozart in Turkey'' || Bassa Selim |- |1999|| ''[[Grizzly Falls]]'' || Genet |- |2003|| ''Half-Empty'' || Lead |- |2003|| ''Method'' || Teddy |- |2005|| ''An Airfield in England'' || Writer/Director |- |2015|| ''[[Dad's Army (2016 film)|Dad's Army]]'' || [[Wilhelm Canaris]] |}
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Television Series !! Role |- |1972–1973|| ''[[Arthur of the Britons]]'' || King Arthur |- |1974|| ''[[Luke's Kingdom]]'' || Luke Firbeck |- |1977|| ''[[Jesus of Nazareth (miniseries)|Jesus of Nazareth]]'' || Joel |- |1980|| ''Smuggler'' || Jack Vincent |- |1985|| ''[[Robin of Sherwood]]'' || Bertrand de Nivelle |- |1985|| ''[[Sherlock Holmes (1984 TV Series)|The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes]]'' || Captain Crocker |- |1986|| ''Mountain Men: A Dangerous Kind of Love'' || Melchior Anderegg |- |1986|| ''Adventurer'' || Jack Vincent |- |1988|| ''Boon'' || |- |1989|| ''Der Schattenspieler'' || |- |1992–1993|| ''Flash – Der Fotoreporter'' || Flash |- |1992|| ''Glückliche Reise'' || Guest Star |- |1992|| ''Donauprinzessin'' || Rick Reimers |- |1993|| ''Das Traumschiff'' || Guest Star |- |1993|| ''Eurocops'' || Crook |- |1995|| ''The Knock II'' || Alan Montfort |- |1996|| ''[[Sharpe's Waterloo (TV programme)|Sharpe's Waterloo]]'' || Colonel Rebecque |- |1997|| ''Real Women'' || Guest Star |- |1998|| ''Klinik unter Palmen'' || Mexican Surgeon |- |1999|| ''Der Bestseller'' || Miguel Gonzales |- |2002|| ''[[Holby City]]'' || |- |2005|| ''Unter weißen Segeln'' || Yussuf Arazi |- |2006|| ''Mord in bester Gesellschaft'' || Comissario Santa Cruz |- |2006|| ''Abschiedsmorgen'' || Father |- |2008|| ''[[Hunkeler macht Sachen]]'' || Thomas Garzoni |}

revision.text:
'''Operation Sudden Fall''' was a 2008 joint operation between the United States [[Drug Enforcement Administration]] and [[San Diego State University]] (SDSU) [[California State University Police Department|campus police]]. It was the largest campus drug bust in [[San Diego County]] history and one of the largest college drug busts in U.S. history.<ref name="Newsweek1">{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=|title=Crime: Inside the San Diego State University Drug Bust|work=[[Newsweek]]|date=May 10, 2008|url=http://www.newsweek.com/crime-inside-san-diego-state-university-drug-bust-90047|accessdate=June 9, 2014}}</ref>
==Background== The sting operation was triggered by the overdose deaths of two students at SDSU in 2007. 19-year Jenny Poliakoff died of a [[cocaine]] overdose on May 6, 2007, and another student, from [[San Diego Mesa College|Mesa College]], died of [[oxycodone]] overdose on February 26, 2008.<ref name="3MonthsLater">{{cite news|last=Littlefield|first=Dana |author2=Jeff McDonald |author3=Sherry Saavedra|title=SDSU drug cases ending with little fanfare|publisher=''[[San Diego Union Tribune]]''|date=2008-08-17|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/education/20080817-9999-1m17sdsu.html|accessdate=2008-08-23}}</ref><ref name="MedicalExaminerOfficial">{{cite news|last=Martinez|first=Angelica |author2=Debbi Farr Baker |author3=Karen Kucher |author4=Sherry Saavedra|title=Sting snares 96 on SDSU campus on drug charges |publisher=''[[San Diego Union Tribune]]''|date=2008-05-06|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/metro/20080506-1620-bn06sdsu3.html|accessdate=2008-12-10}}</ref>
==Results of sting== [[File:ThetaChiSDSUMay08.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The old Theta Chi fraternity house in May 2008. The fraternity was suspended from the SDSU Greek system for four years as a result of the operation's findings.]] On May 6, 2008, San Diego State University Police in collaboration with the [[Drug Enforcement Administration]] culminated a year-long investigation into drug abuse in the college area with a series of early morning raids at several residences in the college area. The DEA initially announced the arrests of 96 individuals, of whom 75 were San Diego State University students, (many of them interns at Adobe Systems Incorporated)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs8.com/misc/SDSU_mug_shots.pdf|title=Mug Shots from Operation Sudden Fall|publisher=CBS News 8|accessdate=2008-05-06 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080530031254/http://www.cbs8.com/misc/SDSU_mug_shots.pdf <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-05-30}}</ref> on a variety of drug charges.<ref>"[http://www.cnn.com/2008/CRIME/05/06/sdsu.bust/index.html Drug bust nets 96 at San Diego State]", CNN.com, May 6, 2008</ref> One day later, on May 7, SDSU officials stated that only 33 were students, and that the inflated numbers issued originally included all drug-related arrests made over the course of the year-long investigation, many of which were months before the raid and most cases for simple possession.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/metro/20080508-1041-bn08arrests.html|title=Officials differ on number of SDSU students snared in sting |publisher=[[San Diego Union Tribune]]|accessdate=2008-05-08}}</ref> Those arrested included students in the campus's Homeland Security and Criminal Justice programs. Additionally, the [[Lambda Chi Alpha]], [[Phi Kappa Theta]], [[Phi Kappa Psi]], [[Sigma Alpha Epsilon]], [[Sigma Alpha Mu]] and [[Theta Chi]] fraternity chapters received interim suspensions, as each had at least one member arrested as result of the investigation. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://advancement.sdsu.edu/marcomm/information/|title=Six SDSU Fraternities Placed On Suspension as a Result of Drug-Related Arrests|publisher=SDSU|accessdate=2008-05-15}}</ref>
Two [[kilograms]] of [[cocaine]] were seized, along with 350 [[Methylenedioxymethamphetamine|Ecstasy]] pills, 50 pounds of [[marijuana]], psychedelic mushrooms, hash oil, methamphetamine, illicit prescription drugs, other drug paraphernalia, three guns, and $60,000 in cash.<ref>[http://origin.mercurynews.com/breakingnews/ci_9178843 origin.mercurynews.com, Six fraternities suspended in drug probe at San Diego State]</ref> That day, SDSU President Stephen Weber spoke at a [[news conference]], while authorities identified 22 SDSU students as drug dealers who sold to undercover agents, and 17 others that had supplied the drugs. The rest of the suspects apparently bought or possessed illegal drugs. Authorities further found that students from seven fraternities were involved in the drug ring, which operated openly across campus.<ref>[http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/metro/20080507-9999-1n7drugs.html signonsandiego.com, 5 are students; DEA took part in yearlong operation]</ref><ref>[http://www.fox6.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=24791aa8-e8a8-4b9e-a987-87b3830d0f51&rss=tick www.fox6.com/news, Family of Dead SDSU Student Reacts to Campus Drug Bust]</ref>
Some student groups, including SDSU group "Students for Sensible Drug Policy," protested the arrests, especially SDSU's decision to involve the DEA, a federal agency, in the operation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/metro/20080508-9999-1n8sdsu.html|title=SDSU drug sting draws scorn, praise |publisher=[[San Diego Union Tribune]]|accessdate=2008-05-08}}</ref> In addition, they called for a more sympathetic policy toward drug use on the campus.<ref name="Newsweek1"/>
On May 15, SDSU Vice President for Student Affairs James Kitchen lifted the interim suspensions from the [[Phi Kappa Theta]], [[Sigma Alpha Mu]], and [[Sigma Alpha Epsilon]] fraternities. The suspension was lifted after an administrative review found that those arrested in connection to the controlled substances investigation were either inactive members of the fraternity and/or were not presently residents of chapter houses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://advancement.sdsu.edu/marcomm/information/|title=SDSU Lifts Interim Suspension on Three Fraternities|publisher=[[San Diego State University]]|accessdate=2008-06-25}}</ref>
On November 22, SDSU announced that [[Phi Kappa Psi]] had been suspended for 18 months and [[Theta Chi]] had been suspended for four years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sdut-1m22frats145710-sdsu-punishes-2-fraternities-2008nov22-story.html|title=SDSU punishes 2 fraternities|publisher=[[San Diego State University]]}}</ref>
==Sentencing== Several months after the May 6 announcement, it was reported that the majority of the defendants had pleaded guilty to the felony charges. The defendants were then either placed on probation or were required to enter drug diversion programs. Other defendants only received citations or had their cases dismissed.<ref name="3MonthsLater"/>
==See also== *[[California State University Police Department]] *[[Wikinews:DEA raids San Diego State University dorms|''DEA raids San Diego State University dorms'' (WikiNews)]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://advancement.sdsu.edu/marcomm/information SDSU President Stephen L. Weber Statement as to SDSU Police 2008 Controlled Substances Investigation] (accessed May 9, 2008) *[http://www.dps.sdsu.edu/ SDSU Department of Public Safety (SDSU Police Department)] {{San Diego State University}}
[[Category:Drug control law in the United States]] [[Category:2008 in law]] [[Category:San Diego State University|Operation Sudden Fall]] [[Category:History of San Diego County, California]] [[Category:2008 in California]] [[Category:Student health]] [[Category:Drug Enforcement Administration operations]]

revision.text:
'''Oslo Waldorf School''' (Norwegian: ''Rudolf Steinerskolen i Oslo'') is a [[Waldorf school]] located in the [[Hovseter]] area in the [[Vestre Aker]] district of [[West End of Oslo|West End]] [[Oslo]], [[Norway]]. It is an integrated primary, middle and high school with around 550 pupils. Founded in 1926, it is one of the oldest Waldorf schools worldwide. It is generally regarded as one of the most prestigious schools in Norway and many of its alumni have been noted in the arts, politics and other areas of society. The school is an independent [[Foundation (nonprofit)|non-profit foundation]] governed by a board consisting of representatives of the teachers and parents, and it is a member of the Norwegian Association of Waldorf Schools.
==History== [[File:Jens Bjørneboe underviser Rudolf Steinerskolen i Oslo 1952.jpg|thumb|Novelist [[Jens Bjørneboe]] teaching at Oslo Waldorf School in 1952]] In November 1921, two years after the first Waldorf School was founded in [[Stuttgart]], Austrian philosopher [[Rudolf Steiner]] held two lectures on education at the [[Norwegian Nobel Institute]] in Oslo (then named Christiania), and the plan to establish a Waldorf school in Oslo was conceived. Among those involved was [[Bokken Lasson]], who also became one of the first teachers when the school was established in 1926. The school was originally located in Oscars gate in the [[Frogner]] district. As of 1932, the school had 102 pupils. Due to financial difficulties, the school had to close in 1936. Vult Simon and Gulle Brun however continued to operate a small Waldorf school in their home at [[Makrellbekken]]. In the autumn of 1945 the school was reestablished, and was located in a barracks in [[Frogner Park]]. In 1949, the school moved to [[Smestad, Oslo|Smestad]], and in 1962, it moved to Hovseter, where it is still located. Its building complex has been successively extended over the years in different architectural styles.
Prior to 1961, the school received no public funding, and was funded entirely by tuition and gifts as well as by idealistic teachers who worked for relatively little pay. The school became entitled to regular public funding under the Private School Act of 1970. Originally a primary school and later also a middle school, the first high school class was established in 1978.
The famous Norwegian novelist [[Jens Bjørneboe]] worked as a teacher at the school in the 1950s and a private school obviously modelled after Oslo Waldorf School has a significant role in his ''[[Jonas (novel)|Jonas]]'' novel, which is noted for its criticism of the public school system. He later published the book ''Under en mykere himmel; brev og bud fra en Steinerskole'' ("Under a softer sky; letters and messages from a Waldorf school") based on his work as a Waldorf teacher.<ref>Erik Marstrander, ''Menneske først! Steinerpedagogikk i Oslo 1926-1996'', Oslo, 1996.</ref> In Norway, [[anthroposophy]] in general and the Waldorf schools in particular have been strongly associated with the cultural and intellectual elite of the country since the early 20th century, and among the school's alumni and parents are many noted individuals, particularly within the arts and the cultural sphere, but also within politics and business.<ref>[http://morgenbladet.no/kultur/2008/hundre_ars_tosomhet?quicktabs_mest_lest_mest_kommentert=0 Hundre års tosomhet], [[Morgenbladet]], 19 Dec 2008</ref> Among the school's alumni is former Labour leader, Prime Minister and now NATO Secretary-General [[Jens Stoltenberg]], and current Labour leader and former Foreign Minister [[Jonas Gahr Støre]] is a parent at the school.<ref>[http://www.vg.no/nyheter/meninger/stoeres-verdivalg/a/520578/ Støres verdivalg], VG</ref> The school and the Waldorf movement in general was a stronghold of the [[Riksmål]] language of the traditional elite during the [[Norwegian language struggle]], and the school is still using the now classic [[alphabet book]] ''André Bjerkes ABC'', published by [[Riksmålsforbundet]] in 1959.<ref>Olav Østrem, [http://www.klassekampen.no/apps/pbcs.dll/article?avis=KK&date=20090910&category=ARTICLE&lopenr=309109996&Ref=AR&profile=1007 På Bjørneboes skuldre], [[Klassekampen]], 10 September 2009</ref>
The arts play a major role in the school curriculum and the broader activities surrounding the school, and the school includes a professionally equipped theater hall.
Due to its long waiting lists, pupils are often enrolled shortly after birth.
==Alumni== [[File:Jens Stoltenberg.jpg|thumb|[[Jens Stoltenberg]], [[Secretary General of NATO]] and former [[Prime Minister of Norway]]]] *[[Jon Almaas]], TV personality *[[Lene Berg]], film director *[[Vilde Bjerke]], actress and author *[[Ketil Bjørnstad]], composer and author *[[Nicolai Cleve Broch]], actor *[[Eindride Eidsvold]], actor *[[Gard Eidsvold]], actor *[[Andreas Galtung]], lawyer, musician and illustrator *[[Erik Fosnes Hansen]], author *[[Kjersti Holmen]], actress *[[Henning Kraggerud]], violinist *[[Odd Nerdrum]], painter *[[Lars Lillo-Stenberg]], singer-songwriter *[[Petter Olsen]], shipping magnate<ref>http://www.dagbladet.no/nyheter/970913-kjent-12.html</ref> *[[Marcus Paus]], composer *[[Kristian Siem]], industrialist<ref>http://www.aftenposten.no/okonomi/Mener-skole-Norge-bor-lare-av-Storbritannia-7522390.html</ref> *[[Njål Sparbo]], opera singer *[[Camilla Stoltenberg]], Director-General of the [[Norwegian Institute of Public Health]]<ref>http://www.dn.no/magasinet/2014/12/26/2129/Portrettet/helsessteren</ref> *[[Jens Stoltenberg]], [[Secretary General of NATO]] and former [[Prime Minister of Norway]] *[[Anneke von der Lippe]], actress *[[Peter Normann Waage]], author *[[Johannes Weisser]], opera singer *[[Nico Widerberg]], sculptor and painter
==References== <references />
==External links== *[http://www.rsio.no Oslo Waldorf School]

{{infobox person |image= |caption=Otto Felix in 2002 |occupation=[[Film]], [[television]] [[actor]],
[[acting]] [[teacher]] |website=http://OttoFelix.com }} '''Otto Felix''' (December 31, 1942 – December 13, 2008){{cite web |url=http://www.malibutimes.com/articles/2008/12/24/obituaries/obit1.txt |title= Otto Felix Obituary }} was a motion picture and television actor, an acting teacher and a still photographer. Raised in [[Pennsylvania]], and a graduate of [[Fishburne Military School]], [[Waynesboro, Virginia]], then he served in the U.S. Army, and worked as a disc jockey in Florida, before beginning an acting career. Felix was cast in over 350 TV commercials after arriving in Hollywood in the early 1970s.{{cite web |url=http://ottofelix.com/OttoFelix-Bio.html |title= Otto Felix Biography }}{{Dubious|date=March 2009}} He played the mellow cop in the [[Cheech and Chong]] feature motion picture ''[[Up in Smoke]]'' (1978). In his later life Otto Felix was an acting teacher based in Hollywood, California. He specialized in actors just getting a start in the fields of film and television acting at his Film Actors Shop that also served as the office for his efforts on behalf of H.A.A.P.I. - Handicapped Artists, Performers & Partners, Inc. that he founded. As a screenwriter, he received a "story by" credit on ''[[South of Heaven, West of Hell (film)|South of Heaven, West of Hell]]'' (2000) a movie western directed by [[Dwight Yoakam]]. Felix authored several books of poems, still photographs and drawings.{{Dubious|date=March 2009}} As a still photographer he shot the cover for Dwight Yoakam's first album [[Guitars, Cadillacs, Etc., Etc.]] (1986). His photographs appeared in ''Time, People, Life, BAM, L.A. Weekly, Billboard, Drama Logue, Variety,'' and ''Photographer.''{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}} He won the Golden Boot Award for Best Country Album and The American Photographers Association Award for best Black & White in 1989 & 99. Felix died unexpectedly on the 13th December 2008 after a short illness, with a diagnosis of amyloidosis. ==Notes== {{more footnotes|date=February 2008}} {{Reflist}} Otto Felix studied radio & television at Cambridge School of Broadcasting, Boston ( Later renamed [[Grahm Junior College]]. ) March 1965, he was a founding Brother, and first President of Delta Omega Delta fraternity. ( originally Delta Phi Delta ) ==External links== *{{IMDb name|0271337}} *[http://groups.msn.com/OfficialOttoFelixFanClub/asiseeit.msnw Fan club] *[http://OttoFelix.com/ Official site] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20021007001833/http://happi-talent.com/ Otto Felix - Founder of H.A.P.P.I.] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080917050256/http://filmactorsshop.com/ Otto Felix - Founder of Film Actors Shop] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090101033813/http://navarredesign.com/otto.html Otto Felix Photos] *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0179473/ South of Heaven, West of Hell] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110717202052/http://videohostusa.com/DY.jpg Dwight Yoakam album cover photo] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Felix, Otto}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:2008 deaths]] [[Category:American male film actors]] [[Category:American male television actors]] [[Category:Drama teachers]] [[Category:United States Army soldiers]] [[Category:American photographers]] [[Category:Fishburne Military School alumni]] {{US-film-actor-1940s-stub}} {{US-tv-actor-1940s-stub}}

A '''pro-chancellor''' is an officer of some [[university|universities]] in [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] countries. The pro-chancellor acts as a deputy to the [[chancellor (education)|chancellor]] and as practical [[chairman]] of the [[university council]]. The actual [[chief executive]] of a university is the [[vice-chancellor]].
==See also== * [[Lists of university leaders]] ** Administrators: [[trustee]], [[president]], [[vice president]], [[principal (university)|university principal]], [[dean (education)|dean]], [[provost (education)|provost]] ** Other: [[college]], [[faculty (teaching staff)|faculty]], [[professor]]

{{Infobox non-profit | name = Project Reason | image = [[File:Project Reason logo.gif|250px|Project Reason Logo]] | founded_date = {{start date and age|2007}} | tax_id = 26-1643643 | founder = {{ubl|[[Sam Harris]]|Annaka Harris}} | location = [[United States]] | mission = Spreading science
and secular values | former name = Reason Project | homepage = {{URL|http://www.project-reason.org/}} }} '''Project Reason''' is a U.S. [[501(c)(3)]] [[Foundation (nonprofit)|foundation]] whose main aims have been variously described as the promotion of [[scientific knowledge]] and [[Secular ethics|secular values]] in [[society]],{{cite web |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2009/10/091005092302.htm |title=Where Religious Belief And Disbelief Meet |author= University of California - Los Angeles |date=11 October 2010 |publisher=ScienceDaily}}{{cite web |url=http://bigthink.com/ideas/16122 |title=How Atheists Bow Down to the God of Reason |first=Catman |last=Cohen |date=30 August 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/sam-harris/bringing-the-vatican-to-j_b_571088.html |title=Bringing the Vatican to Justice |first=Sam |last=Harris |date=10 May 2010 |publisher= Huffington Post}} and the encouragement of critical thinking and wise public policy through a variety of interrelated projects.https://web.archive.org/web/20150815061048/http://www.project-reason.org/#sthash.KFnWAt17.dpuf ==History== In 2007, [[Sam Harris]] co-founded, alongside his wife, the (501(c)3) non-profit foundation called Project Reason. Harris is also chief executive of this organization. Its website describes itself in the following terms:
Project Reason is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit foundation devoted to spreading scientific knowledge and secular values in society. The project will draw on the talents of prominent and creative [[Intellectual|thinkers]] from a wide range of disciplines—[[science]], [[law]], [[literature]], [[entertainment]], [[information technology]], etc.—to encourage [[critical thinking]] and wise public policy. It will convene conferences, produce films, sponsor scientific research and opinion polls, award grants to other non-profit organizations, and offer material support to [[Dissident|religious dissidents]] and public intellectuals—with the purpose of eroding the influence of dogmatism, superstition and bigotry in the world.{{cite web |url=http://www.project-reason.org/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100306140031/http://www.project-reason.org/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2010-03-06 |title=Project Reason |df= }}
==Projects== The organization maintains several projects, as well as an internet forum, that attempt to debunk religion using empirical and rational critiques. ''The Scripture Project'', undertaken under the mantle of Project Reason, stated the following as its goal:
Steve Wells, creator of the Skeptics Annotated Bible, Qur'an, and Book of Mormon has generously donated the full contents of his website to Project Reason. Using this as a foundation, we intend to make the Scripture Project the best source for scriptural criticism on the Internet.https://web.archive.org/web/20150418140718/http://www.project-reason.org/scripture_project
''Vatican Justice'', another project undertaken by Project Reason, has the following as its mission statement:
I would like to announce that Project Reason has joined Hitchens and Dawkins (both of whom sit on our advisory board) in an effort to end the "diplomatic immunity" which the Vatican claims protects the Pope from any responsibility. We would greatly appreciate your support in this cause. All donations are tax-deductible in the United States.https://web.archive.org/web/20150418141200/http://www.project-reason.org/vatican_justice
==The Secular Islam Sub-Project== One of the most active sub-projects in Project Reason is the ''Secular Islam'' sub-project, with several initiatives falling under it. One project within Secular Islam is titled "Modern Developments in Koranic Criticism: Christmas in the Koran" with the following description:
This project is being run by foundation advisor Ibn Warraq and takes as its focus the pioneering work in Syriac and Arabic linguistics of Christof Luxenberg. Luxenberg is a native Arab speaker and linguist, living in the West and writing under a pseudonym. Luxenberg's work has given new impetus to the discipline of Koranic studies, largely by revealing that many acknowledged obscurities in the Koran can be clarified by treating certain passages as a poor translations of Syriac into Arabic.https://web.archive.org/web/20150418132933/http://www.project-reason.org/secular_islam
The Secular Islam sub-project supports other projects, such as ''The Institute for Research on Early Islamic History and the Koran'', having funded their conferences in 2008, 2012, and 2014. It pledges collaboration with the Ayaan Hirsi Ali Foundation, supports the Ex-Muslims of North America, and the Quilliam Foundation. ==Trustees and Advisory board== The organization listed three trustees: Sam Harris, Annaka Harris, and Jai Lakshman. Advisory board: * Clifford S Asness — Managing and Founding Principal of AQR Capital Management (quit the board June 2010) * [[Peter Atkins]] — professor of chemistry at the [[University of Oxford]] * [[Jerry Coyne]] — professor in the Department of Ecology and Evolution at the [[University of Chicago]] * [[Richard Dawkins]] — former Charles Simonyi Professor of the Public Understanding of Science at the [[University of Oxford]] * [[Daniel C. Dennett]] — Austin B. Fletcher Professor of Philosophy, and co-director of the [[Center for Cognitive Studies]] at [[Tufts University]] * [[Brent Forrester]] — [[Emmy Award]]-winning television writer * [[Ricky Gervais]] — (Joined around June 2011) * [[Rebecca Goldstein]] — philosopher and novelist * [[A. C. Grayling|Anthony Grayling]] — Professor of Philosophy at Birbeck College, University of London * [[Ayaan Hirsi Ali]] — former member of the [[States-General of the Netherlands|Dutch parliament]]; author of ''[[The Caged Virgin]]'' and the ''New York Times'' best selling memoir ''[[Infidel]]'' * [[Christopher Hitchens]] — (''now deceased'') author, journalist, and literary critic; author of ''[[God Is Not Great]]'' * [[Lawrence Krauss]] — Foundation Professor in the School of Earth and Space Exploration and Physics Departments, Associate Director of the Beyond Center, Co-Director of the Cosmology Initiative and Director of the Origins Initiative at Arizona State University * [[Harold Kroto]] — chairman of the board of the Vega Science Trust; [[List of Nobel laureates|Nobel laureate]] in chemistry, 1996 * [[Janna Levin]] — (Joined early 2011) * [[Bill Maher]] — comedian, pundit, writer, and host of ''[[Real Time with Bill Maher]]'' * [[Ian McEwan]] — award-winning novelist * Dan Pallotta — nonprofit innovator and social entrepreneur. Founder of Pallotta TeamWorks. * [[Steven Pinker]] — Johnstone Family Professor in the Department of Psychology at [[Harvard University]] * [[Carolyn Porco]] — (Joined early 2011) * [[Salman Rushdie]] — [[Man Booker Prize]]-winning author * [[Lee M. Silver]] — professor at [[Princeton University]] in the Department of Molecular Biology * [[Craig Venter|J. Craig Venter]] — biologist and entrepreneur known for being one of the first to sequence the human genome and for creating the first cell with a synthetic genome. * [[Ibn Warraq]] — senior research fellow at the [[Center for Inquiry]] specializing in Koranic criticism * [[Steven Weinberg]] — Josey Regental Chair in Science at the [[University of Texas at Austin]]; Nobel laureate in physics, 1979 ==See also== * [[Atheism]] * [[Richard Dawkins Foundation for Reason and Science]] * [[Secular humanism]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.project-reason.org/}} (inactive) [[Category:Skeptic organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Scientific skepticism]] [[Category:Critical thinking]] [[Category:Humanist associations]] [[Category:Foundations based in the United States]] [[Category:2007 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2007]]

{{italic title}} [[Image:Ratiostudiorum.jpg|thumb|right|The ''Ratio Studiorum'', dated 1598, formally issued in 1599]]
The '''''Ratio atque Institutio Studiorum Societatis Iesu''''' (''The Official Plan for Jesuit Education''), often abbreviated as '''''Ratio Studiorum''''' ([[Latin language|Latin]]: ''Plan of Studies''), was a document that standardized the globally influential system of [[Jesuit]] education in 1599. It was a collection of regulations for school officials and teachers. The ''Ratio Studiorum'' relied on the classical subjects (theology, philosophy, Latin and Greek) and did not contain any provisions for elementary education. The document was revised in 1832, still built upon the classical subjects but giving more attention to the study of native languages of the students, history, geography, mathematics, and the natural sciences.
The work was the product of many hands and wide experience, but it most directly derives from the efforts of an international team of academics at the [[Collegio Romano]], the Jesuit school in [[Rome]]. The ''Ratio'' had a major impact on later humanist education. In his ''Renaissance Literary Theory and Practice,'' Charles Sears Baldwin writes, "The sixteenth century closed with the full [classical] doctrine operative in the Ratio Studiorum and in the rhetoric of [[Cypriano de Soarez|Soarez]]" (64).<ref>Baldwin, Charles Sears. Renaissance Literary Theory and Practice. New York: Columbia UP, 1939.</ref>
==Historical background== The [[Society of Jesus]] had not originally envisaged running a network of schools when it was founded, but it soon became progressively involved in and then largely associated with educational work. One hundred years after the order's founding, the Jesuits were running 444 schools. By 1739, they were running 669 schools.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Moss |first1=Jean Dietz |first2=William A. |last2=Wallace |title=Rhetoric & Dialectic in the Time of Galileo |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Lw50esHmgacC&pg=PA118 |location= Washington, D.C. |publisher=Catholic UP |year=2003 |page=118 |isbn=9780813213316}}</ref> The many schools taken over or started by the Society in its first decades all needed plans (''rationes''). In addition, an increasing number of young men were entering the Society in need of the educational background that was required for priestly service, and the Society began to assume a greater and greater role in the direction of its own formational program. For these two reasons, there grew a great desire for a standard plan for all of the Society's educational institutions.
Under the generalate of [[Claudio Aquaviva]], in 1581, a committee of twelve Jesuit priests was appointed without clear results. A new committee of six was soon formed in 1584: [[John Azor|Juan Azor]] ([[Spain]]), [[Gaspar González]] ([[Portugal]]), [[James Tyrie]] ([[Scotland]]), [[Peter Busée]] (the [[Netherlands]]), [[Anthony Ghuse]] ([[Flanders]]), and [[Stephen Tucci]] ([[Sicily]]). This committee produced a trial document, the ''Ratio'' of 1586, which was sent to various provinces for comments from the teachers. This plan was not intended for actual use in the classrooms. Reflection on the reactions led to the issuance of another document in 1591, which was to be employed in all Jesuit schools for three years. The reflection on these experiments was then used by the committee in Rome to create the final official document of 1599.
==Content== The ''Ratio Studiorum'' was divided into the following sections:<ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/12654a.htm Catholic Encyclopedia article on the Ratio Studiorum]</ref>
I. Rules for the [[provincial superior]]; for the rector of the college; for the prefect of studies, who supervises classes and instruction, and the prefect of discipline, who maintains order and discipline;
II. Rules for the professors of theology: [[Scripture]], [[Hebrew language]], [[dogmatic theology]], [[ecclesiastical history]], [[canon law]], and [[moral theology]]. [[St. Thomas Aquinas]] was the main author for theological texts.
III. Rules for the professors of philosophy, physics, and mathematics. [[Aristotle]] was prescribed as the standard author.
IV. Rules for the teachers of the ''studia inferiora'' (the lower department): Latin and Greek, grammar and syntax, humanities and [[rhetoric]]. Other subjects were taught from the beginning under the name of "accessories"—especially history, geography, and antiquities.
==See also==
* [[Manoel Alvarez]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * ''Ratio atque Institutio Studiorum Societatis Iesu''. Volume 5 of the ''Monumenta Paedagogica Societatis Iesu'', ed. Ladislaus Lukàcs. Volume 129 of the series ''[[Monumenta Historica Societatis Iesu]]'', 357-454. Rome: Institutum Historicum Societatis Iesu, 1986. * Abbott, Don Paul. “Rhetoric and Writing in the Renaissance.” ''A Short History of Writing Instruction''. Ed. James J. Murphy. Mahwah, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum, 2001. 145–72. * Atteberry, John. “Humanities and Rhetoric.”'' Ratio Studiorum: Jesuit Education 1540–1773''. Ed. John Atteberry and John Russell. Boston: John J. Burns Library, 1999. * Baldwin, Charles Sears. ''Renaissance Literary Theory and Practice''. New York: Columbia UP, 1939. * Donohue, John W., S.J. ''Jesuit Education: An Essay on the Foundation of Its Idea''. New York: Fordham University Press, 1963. * Farrell, Allan Peter, S.J. ''The Jesuit Code of Liberal Education; Development and Scope of the Ratio Studiorum.'' Milwaukee: Bruce Publishing Company, 1938. * Ganss, George, S.J. ''Saint Ignatius' Idea of a Jesuit University''. Second Edition. Milwaukee: Marquette University Press, 1956. * Pavur, Claude, S.J. ''The Ratio Studiorum: The Official Plan for Jesuit Education''. Saint Louis: The Institute of Jesuit Sources, 2005. * Scaglione, Aldo. ''The Liberal Arts and the Jesuit College System''. Philadelphia: John Benjamins Publishing Company, 1986. * Schwickerath, Robert, S.J. ''Jesuit Education: Its History and Principles Viewed in the Light of Modern Educational Problems''. Saint Louis, Missouri: B. Herder, 1903.
==External links== *[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/12654a.htm ''Catholic Encyclopedia'' article on the Ratio Studiorum] *[http://www.slu.edu/colleges/AS/languages/classical/latin/tchmat/pedagogy/schw/schw1.html "The Method of Teaching in Practice," a chapter from ''Jesuit Education: Its History and Principles Viewed in the Light of Modern Educational Problems'' by Robert Schwickerath, S.J. (with bibliography)] *[http://bc.edu/sites/libraries/ratio/ratio1599.pdf Translation of the ''Ratio Studiorum'' by Allan P. Farrell, S.J., available in PDF or HTML]
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Jesuit education]] [[Category:Jesuit publications]] [[Category:History of education]] [[Category:1599 books]]

{{distinguish|Rhodes Scholarship|Road Scholars|roads scholar}} {{advert|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox company | name = Road Scholar | former_name = Exploritas | logo = Image:Road Scholar Logo.jpg | type = Corporate | foundation = 1975 | location = [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]] | location_country = [[United States]] | num_employees = 270 | industry = Educational travel | homepage = {{url|roadscholar.org}} }}
'''Road Scholar''' is an American [[not-for-profit organization]] that provides [[Educational tourism|educational travel tours]] primarily geared to [[older adults]]. The organization is headquartered in [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]]. From its founding in 1975 until 2010, Road Scholar was known as Elderhostel. Road Scholar offers study tours throughout the [[United States]] and [[Canada]] and in approximately 150 other countries.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Flinn|first1=John|title=Road Scholar: Former Elderhostel still about learning|url=http://www.sfgate.com/travel/article/Road-Scholar-Former-Elderhostel-still-about-3655907.php|accessdate=2 June 2014|work=San Francisco Chronicle|date=22 June 2012}}</ref>
==History== Elderhostel was founded in 1975 by friends [[Martin Knowlton|Marty Knowlton]], social activist and self-described [[hippie]], and [[David Bianco (educator)|David Bianco]], director of residential life at the [[University of New Hampshire]]. Knowlton rejected as [[ageism]] the belief that one's mind must fail as one ages. After four years of [[Backpacking (travel)|backpacking]] through Europe and staying in [[hostels]], Knowlton, then in his 50s, returned to the United States to direct the youth hostel program at the University of New Hampshire. There, he and Bianco, the university administrator, decided that society needed "elderhostels" in addition to youth hostels.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nelson|first1=Valerie J.|title=Martin P. 'Marty' Knowlton dies at 88; co-founder of Elderhostel|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/obituaries/la-me-marty-knowlton18-2009mar18-story.html|accessdate=2 June 2014|work=Los Angeles Times|date=18 March 2009}}</ref>
The program started in the summer of 1975, offering older adults [[Academic audit|noncredit classes]] and [[dormitory]] housing on [[campus]]es in [[New England]]<ref name="Travelers Wanted">{{cite news|last1=Greene|first1=Kelly|title=Travelers Wanted|url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052970204563304574316862522747686|work=Wall Street Journal|date=19 September 2009}}</ref> — a sort of "[[summer school]] for retired people."<ref name="San Francisco Chronicle">{{cite news|last1=Flinn|first1=John|title=Road Scholar: Former Elderhostel still about learning|url=http://www.sfgate.com/travel/article/Road-Scholar-Former-Elderhostel-still-about-3655907.php#page-1|accessdate=2 June 2014|work=San Francisco Chronicle|date=22 June 2012}}</ref> Elderhostel was officially established as a not-for-profit organization in 1977. Its program offerings expanded through the United States and Canada, and eventually internationally. By the 1990s, more than 200,000 people were learning with Elderhostel each year.<ref name="Travelers Wanted"/>
In 2010, Elderhostel changed its name to Road Scholar in order to appeal to the next wave of older travelers: [[Baby Boomers]]. [[CEO]] James Moses explained the name change to the [[San Francisco Chronicle]]: "Hostel" no longer accurately described the [[lodging]] offered on the programs and "Baby Boomers, even when they're in their 60s, don't like to think of themselves as 'elders,'" he said.<ref name="San Francisco Chronicle"/> For a few months during 2010, the company was called Exploritas before changing its name to Road Scholar.
==Educational programs== Road Scholar now includes 5,500 programs, dividing them into the categories of theme-based, inter-generational, outdoor adventures, service learning, adventures afloat, and independent city discoveries.
==Scholarships== Elderhostel extends approximately $300,000 yearly in [[scholarships]] to North American participants who might otherwise be unable to attend a Road Scholar program <ref name="guidestar1">{{cite web|url=http://www2.guidestar.org/organizations/04-2632526/elderhostel.aspx |title=GuideStar Exchange Reports for Elderhostel, Inc |publisher=.guidestar.org |date= |accessdate=2012-01-07}}</ref>
==Research and grants== Elderhostel conducts research on aging and lifelong learning.<ref name="guidestar1"/> Research articles include:“What Will Baby Boomers Want from Educational Travel,” and “Mental Stimulation and Lifelong Learning Activities in the 55+ Population.”
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.roadscholar.org/ Official website]
[[Category:Adult education]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Boston]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1975]] [[Category:Seniors' organizations]] [[Category:Travel and holiday companies of the United States]] [[Category:Lifelong learning]] [[Category:1975 establishments in New Hampshire]]

{{for|the talk show host|Stanley Siegel (talk show host)}} {{orphan|date=January 2016}}
{{Infobox writer <!-- For more information see [[:Template:Infobox Writer/doc]]. --> | name = Stanley Siegel, LCSW [[File:Stanley Siegel.jpg|thumb|Stanley Siegel]] | occupation = Author, Psychotherapist, Lecturer, Professor | notableworks = ''The Patient Who Cured His Therapist and Other Unconventional Stories Of Therapy'', ''Uncharted Lives: Understanding The Life Passages Of Gay Men'' | website = {{URL|http://stanley-siegel.com/}} }}
'''Stanley Siegel''', [[LCSW]], is a [[psychotherapist]], [[author]], [[lecturer]], and former Director of Education and Senior Faculty member of New York's Ackerman Institute for Family Therapy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ackerman.org/ |title=Ackerman Institute for the Family |publisher=Ackerman.org |date= |accessdate=2011-08-03}}</ref>
After creating and writing the "Families" column for ''[[Newsday]]'' he went on to co-author two popular books: ''The Patient Who Cured His Therapist and Other Unconventional Stories Of Therapy''<ref>{{cite web|last=Miller |first=William R. |url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/1569246858 |title=The Patient Who Cured His Therapist: And Other Stories of Unconventional Therapy (9781569246856): Stanley Siegel, Ed Lowe: Books |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2011-08-03}}</ref> (Penguin/Dutton 1992; Penguin/Plume, 1993; Marlowe and company, 1999) and ''Uncharted Lives: Understanding The Life Passages Of Gay Men''<ref>{{cite web|last=Shepard |first=Judy |url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/0452274486 |title=Uncharted Lives: Understanding the Life Passages of Gay Men (9780452274488): Stanley Siegel, Ed Lowe: Books |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2011-08-03}}</ref> (Penguin/Dutton, 1994; Penguin/Plume 1995) which have been translated into 5 languages.
With over 36 years of experience in the field of psychology, Siegel has developed an unconventional and tradition-challenging approach to psychotherapy<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/08/16/books/therapist-shrink-thyself.html |title=Therapist, Shrink Thyself - New York Times |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=1992-08-16 |accessdate=2011-08-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=submit a syllabus<!-- .Padding --> |url=http://www.bookforum.com/booklist/5099 |title=secret self-help - bookforum.com / syllabi |publisher=Bookforum.com |date=2010-02-03 |accessdate=2011-08-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Siegel |first=Stanley |url=http://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/non-fiction/stanley-siegel/uncharted-lives/#review |title=UNCHARTED LIVES by Stanley Siegel | Kirkus Book Reviews |publisher=Kirkusreviews.com |date=1994-06-13 |accessdate=2011-08-03}}</ref> that has led to his book ''Your Brain on Sex: How Smarter Sex Can Change Your Life''<ref>https://www.amazon.com/dp/1402253923</ref> which was released in October, 2011.
Siegel has taught at the [[State University of New York at Stony Brook]], [[Adelphi University]], and the [[University of California, Berkeley]]; was the founding Director of the Family Studies Center in Huntington, New York, and has served as a consultant to hospitals and mental health centers throughout the country.
Regularly quoted in the media, he has appeared on ABC's ''[[Good Morning America]]'' several times,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.locatetv.com/tv/good-morning-america/1084971 |title=Good Morning America - EPISODE: 42 |publisher=LocateTV |date= |accessdate=2011-08-03}}</ref> as well as many other television and radio programs, and has acted as a consultant for film and television. Siegel was invited on ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'' to discuss "How Healers Heal Themselves."
He served as the Dance Editor of ''[[Show Business (magazine)|Show Business]]'' magazine, writing weekly dance reviews and reporting on the contemporary dance scene.
His daughter, Alyssa Siegel, [[Licensed Professional Counselor|LPC]] lives in Portland, Oregon and is a contributor to ''Your Brain on Sex''.
He lives in [[New York City]].
